723732f-a.text:
(1)
Varick Street (left to right), at adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Laight Street, showing a portion of St. John's Chapel and the church yard. The church and the 3-story house adjoining it have been demolished and its site is now (1937) occupied by station V of the United States Post Office.
About 1914.
Gift of Samuel Landsman.
(2)
A portion of the same, showing the lower part of the 3-story house seen in view No. 1. It was then known as Trinity Hospital.
About 1914.
Gift of Samuel Landeman.
723732f-a.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723732f-b.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723730f-c.text:
(1)
Nos. 56-26 Varick Street, east side, south from Laight (left) to Beach (right) Streets, as seen from Hudson Street, and across the site of the former New York Central Freight Depot.  The 4-story structure shown (Nos. 50-34) is a United States Post Office.  Prominently shown in the background, is the New York Telephone Building.
November 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the S.E. corner at Laight Street.  Buildings shown on the left, are on the north side of Canal Street, between Thompson and West Broadway.
December 5, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
From the same position as No. 1, but viewing more northward toward the Sixth Ave. Extension, which intersects Canal Street.  On the left, appears the N.W. corner of Laight Street.  St. Alphonsus R.C. Church and School (Nos. 4-10 Thompson Street), is seen across the afore mentioned extension.
November 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
723730f-c.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723727f-b.text:
(1)
Varick Street, east side, between Laight (left) and Beach (right) Streets, as seen across clearance (site of former N.Y. Central R.R. Depot) from Hudson Street. The 4-story building, occupying the center or the aforementioned block front, is a U.S. Post Office. Prominent building shown. (background), is the N.Y. Telephone Building.
May 20, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A closer view of the P.O. Building. This view is seen from Laight Street
May 20, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view more to the south, as seen from the same point of vantage as No. 2, and showing the Beach Street intersection. The buildings on the right (Merchants Refrigerating Co., and 4th Precinct Police Station) are on Ericsson Place (formerly Beach Street).
May 20, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723728f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, south of Laight to Beach Streets (right), showing mainly the distinctive St. John's P. E. Chapel, built by Trinity Church in 1803-7. The front presents a high Corinthian porch, supported by four massive columns of sandstone. The quaint hewn-oak spire, with a clock tower, rises 214 feet above the surrounding depreciated locale.
About 1915
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723728f-a.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723729f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, south of Laight, to Beach (right)
Street's, showing St. John's P. E. Chapel.
About 1900'S
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723729f-a.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723733f-a.text:
(I)
Varick Street,left to right,adjoining the South East corner of Laight Street,and showing St.John's Church erected in 1807. It
was demolished in 1911.
About 1900
P.L.Sperr.

(2)
Varick Street,South East corner of Laight Street,showing St.John's
Church Parsonage,now demolished.
About 1900
P.L.Sperr.

723734f-a.text:
Varick Street, north from and including Laight Street, south
of Canal Street.
April 2, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
723734f-a.folder: Varick Street & Laight Street, Manhattan, NY

723735f-a.text:
(1)
Varick Street, at the S.W. corner of Laight Street. Shown under demolition is the old New York Central Freight Depot. Prominent building in the background, is the Holland Plaza Building, and is at the N.W. corner of Canal at Varick Streets.
September 17, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A close-up of the corner.
September 17, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Further demolition; several weeks later.
October 21, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
